{{United States constitutional law}} [[Article Two of the United States Constitution|Article Two]], Section 1 of the United States Constitution sets forth the eligibility requirements for serving as President of the United States:
{{quote|No person except a natural born Citizen, or a Citizen of the United States, at the time of the Adoption of this Constitution, shall be eligible to the Office of President; neither shall any person be eligible to that Office who shall not have attained to the Age of thirty-five Years, and been fourteen Years a Resident within the United States.<ref name="frwebgate.access.gpo.gov">[http://frwebgate.access.gpo.gov/cgi-bin/getdoc.cgi?dbname=105_cong_documents&docid=f:sd011.105.pdf The U.S. Constitution With Declaration of Independence, US Government Printing Office]</ref>}}
The [[Twenty-second Amendment to the United States Constitution]] also sets constraints on who may be elected to the Presidency:
{{quote|No person shall be elected to the office of the President more than twice, and no person who has held the office of President, or acted as President, for more than two years of a term to which some other person was elected President shall be elected to the office of the President more than once.<ref name="frwebgate.access.gpo.gov">[http://frwebgate.access.gpo.gov/cgi-bin/getdoc.cgi?dbname=105_cong_documents&docid=f:sd011.105.pdf The U.S. Constitution With Declaration of Independence, US Government Printing Office]</ref>}}
The controversy arising from [[Barack Obama citizenship conspiracy theories|conspiracy theories over Barack Obama's citizenship and eligibility for the presidency]] prompted a number of Republican state and federal legislators to propose legislation aimed at requiring future presidential candidates to release copies of their birth certificates. The Hawaii State legislature went in the opposite direction, to limit the lengths that proponents can go in pursuit of this issue, as the pursuits have drained resources from the state.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.politico.com/blogs/bensmith/0510/Hawaiis_birther_bill.html|title=Hawaii's 'birther bill'|last=Smith|first=Ben|authorlink=Ben Smith (journalist)|date=May 13, 2010|publisher=[[Politico (newspaper)|Politico]]}}</ref>
==Federal initiatives==
===Electoral College=== Activists lobbied members of Congress to reject the Electoral College vote and block Obama's election as president in its sitting on January 8, 2009, to certify and tally the results of the election. Two Republican members of the [[United States House of Representatives|House of Representatives]], [[John Linder]] and [[Ron Paul]], were heavily lobbied by activists who believed that the two lawmakers would be more willing than other members of Congress to raise objections to Obama's confirmation.<ref name="Weigel-GOP"/> The lobbying was unsuccessful and Congress unanimously declared Obama to be the winner of the election.<ref name="Abrams-Congress">{{cite news|title=Congress Declares Obama the Next President|first=Jim|last=Abrams|url=http://seattletimes.nwsource.com/html/politics/2008603247_apelectoralvotes.html|agency=[[Associated Press]]|publisher=Seattle Times|location=[[Seattle]], [[Washington (state)|Washington]]|date=2009-01-08|accessdate=2010-06-12|quote=In centuries-old tradition, Congress confirms Obama as the next president}}</ref>
===Birth certificate=== {{redirect|H.R. 1503|the star|Beta Caeli}} {{wikisource|H.R. 1503 (2009)}}In March 2009, Representative [[Bill Posey]], a newly elected Republican from [[Florida's 15th congressional district]], introduced a bill, H.R. 1503, in the U.S. House of Representatives. Had this bill been enacted into law, it would have amended the [[Federal Election Campaign Act]] of 1971 to require candidates for the Presidency "to include with the [campaign] committee's statement of organization a copy of the candidate's birth certificate" plus supporting documentation.<ref>{{cite news |first=Ben|last=Smith |title=Birther bill hits Congress |url=http://www.politico.com/blogs/bensmith/0309/Birther_bill_hits_Congress.html?showall |work=Politico.com |date=March 13, 2009|accessdate=March 13, 2009}}</ref> The bill did not initially have any co-sponsors and was introduced without the Republican leadership being informed.<ref>{{cite news |first=Mark|last=Preston |title=Republican wants WH candidates to prove citizenship |url=http://politicalticker.blogs.cnn.com/2009/03/13/gop-congressman-wants-presidential-candidates-to-prove-citizenship/ |work=Political Ticker blog |publisher=CNN|date=March 13, 2009|accessdate=March 13, 2009}}</ref> ''[[Florida Today]]'', the newspaper serving his constituency, commented that the bill "stems from fringe opponents of President Barack Obama who, during the 2008 election campaign, questioned whether Obama was born in Hawaii," but added that Posey's office "does not question Obama's citizenship."<ref>{{cite news|author=Kim Eun Kyung|title=Posey to president hopefuls: Prove it|url=http://www.tcpalm.com/news/2009/mar/16/posey-president-hopefuls-prove-it/|work=[[Florida Today]]|date=March 14, 2009|accessdate=March 14, 2011}}</ref> Posey explained his motivation as being to "prevent something like this [controversy] from happening in the future" by requiring "the birth certificate up front and take [the issue] off the table". His initiative was strongly criticized by Florida Democrats, who accused Posey of trying to "fan the rumors on the extreme fringe of the Republican Party" and "pandering to the right wing".<ref>{{cite news |first=Mark|last=Matthews |title=Posey: Future presidential candidates should show their birth certificates; won't say whether he believes Obama is a US citizen |url=http://blogs.orlandosentinel.com/news_politics/2009/03/posey-future-presidential-candidates-should-show-their-birth-certificates-wont-say-whether-he-believ.html |work=[[Orlando Sentinel]]|location=Florida|date=March 13, 2009|accessdate=2009-03-13|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090319082319/http://blogs.orlandosentinel.com/news_politics/2009/03/posey-future-presidential-candidates-should-show-their-birth-certificates-wont-say-whether-he-believ.html|archivedate=2009-03-19}}</ref>
Satirist [[Stephen Colbert]] also mocked Posey for not addressing rumors that he was "part alligator";<ref>{{cite news |last=Colbert|first=Stephen |title=Bill Posey Alligator Rumors |url=http://www.colbertnation.com/the-colbert-report-videos/222213/march-19-2009/bill-posey-alligator-rumors |work=The Colbert Report|date=March 19, 2009|accessdate=June 23, 2009}}</ref> Posey responded by commenting that there was "no reason to say that I'm the illegitimate grandson of an alligator". He also stated that there was now "no reason to question" that Obama is a U.S. citizen.<ref>{{cite news |last = Matthews |first = Mark K. |title = New Rep. Bill Posey gains his footing after rough start |work = The Orlando Sentinel |url = http://www.orlandosentinel.com/news/local/orl-asec-posey-040909,0,6201727.story |date = April 9, 2009 |accessdate = September 14, 2010 |archive-url = https://web.archive.org/web/20090413183806/http://www.orlandosentinel.com/news/local/orl-asec-posey-040909,0,6201727.story# |archive-date = 2009-04-13 |dead-url = yes |df = }}</ref>
Posey's bill gained the support of twelve Republican co-sponsors - Representatives [[John Carter (Texas)|John R. Carter]], [[Kenny Marchant]], [[Louie Gohmert]], [[John Culberson]], [[Randy Neugebauer]], [[Mike Conaway]] and [[Ted Poe]] (all from Texas), Rep. [[John B. T. Campbell III|John Campbell]] (California), Rep. [[Bob Goodlatte]] (Virginia), Rep. [[Dan Burton]] (Indiana), Rep. [[Marsha Blackburn]] (Tennessee), and Rep. [[Trent Franks]] (Arizona).<ref>[http://thomas.loc.gov/cgi-bin/bdquery/z?d111:HR01503:@@@P Bill Summary & Status: 111th Congress (2009 - 2010): H.R.1503: Cosponsors]</ref><ref>[http://thomas.loc.gov/ thomas.loc.govthomas.loc.gov].</ref> Republican Senator [[Tom Coburn]] (Oklahoma) also stated that he would "likely support it" if the bill reached the Senate, saying that Obama "meets the constitutional requirement to be president," and that "It is each state's responsibility to determine the eligibility of those running for federal office."<ref>{{cite news |last=Smith|first=Ben |title=Coburn backing Birther bill |url=http://www.politico.com/blogs/bensmith/0609/Coburn_backing_Birther_bill.html |work=Politico.com |date=June 19, 2009|accessdate=June 23, 2009}}</ref> H.R. 1503 was never voted upon by either house of Congress and died when the [[111th United States Congress|111th Congress]] adjourned at the end of 2010.<ref>[http://thomas.loc.gov/cgi-bin/bdquery/z?d111:HR01503: Bill Summary & Status: 111th Congress (2009 - 2010): H.R.1503]</ref>
===Hawaii statehood===
On July 27, 2009, the [[United States House of Representatives|House of Representatives]] passed a resolution commemorating the 50th anniversary of Hawaii's statehood. The resolution, containing language recognizing Hawaii as President Obama's birth state, passed by a vote of 378 to 0.<ref>{{cite news |last=Stein|first=Sam |title=Resolution Proclaiming Hawaii Obama's Birthplace Passes House Unanimously |url=http://www.huffingtonpost.com/2009/07/27/house-to-consider-counter_n_245741.html |work=The Huffington Post |date=July 27, 2009|accessdate=July 27, 2009}}</ref> Some of the cosponsors of the Posey bill, namely [[John B. T. Campbell III|Campbell]], [[John Carter (Texas)|Carter]] and [[Kenny Marchant|Marchant]], did not cast a vote.<ref>{{cite web|title=Final vote results for roll call 647 |publisher=Clerk of the House of Representatives|date=July 27, 2009 |url=http://clerk.house.gov/evs/2009/roll647.xml|accessdate=July 28, 2009}}</ref> The House has 435 members when all seats are filled.
==State initiatives==
===Alabama=== Legislation introduced in April 2011 by state Senator [[Slade Blackwell]] would require any candidate running for an office with an age requirement to present their birth certificate.<ref>{{cite news|title=DANA BEYERLE: Have senators offered 'birther' bill? |url=http://www.gadsdentimes.com/article/20110422/NEWS/110429923/-1/news02?Title=DANA-BEYERLE-Have-senators-offered-birther-bill-&tc=ar|first=Dana|last=Beyerle|date=April 22, 2011|publisher=[[Gadsden Times]]}}</ref>
===Arizona=== On April 19, 2010, the [[Arizona House of Representatives]] voted in favor of a [[Rider (legislation)|rider]] to require presidential candidates "to submit documents proving they meet the constitutional requirements to be president".<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.myfoxphoenix.com/dpp/news/politics/state_politics/house-oks-birther-bill-4-19-2010|title=Ariz House: Check Obama's Citizenship|date=April 19, 2010}}</ref> If enacted, the law would give the Arizona Secretary of State the power to omit a candidate's name on the state ballot if there is "reasonable cause" to believe that the documents are not adequate proof of the requirements for office. The rider passed the Arizona House of Representatives on a 31–29 vote, with only Republicans voting in favor and some Republicans joining with Democrats to oppose.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://voices.washingtonpost.com/right-now/2010/04/arizonas_birthers_they_have_no.html|title=Arizona birthers: No clue, but plenty of company|date=April 21, 2010|work=The Washington Post}}</ref> The bill then went to the [[Arizona Senate|Arizona State Senate]], which declined to vote on the bill before the April 2010 end of legislative session, the deadline for the bill's passage.<ref>{{Cite news|title=Arizona 'birther bill' won't get Senate vote|url=http://www.azcentral.com/news/articles/2010/04/29/20100429arizona-birther-bill-stalls.html|date=April 29, 2010|work=[[The Arizona Republic]]|location=Phoenix, Arizona|agency=[[Associated Press]]|postscript=|accessdate=June 7, 2010}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=Welcome to the Arizona State Legislature|url=http://www.azleg.gov/|publisher=[[Arizona Legislature]]|location=Phoenix, Arizona|quote=The 49th Legislature, 2nd Regular Session Adjourned Sine Die on Thursday, April 29, 2010 at 11:07 p.m.|postscript=|accessdate=June 7, 2010}}</ref><ref name="AZbillstatus">{{cite web|title=Bill Status Overview – SB1024|url=http://www.azleg.gov/FormatDocument.asp?inDoc=/legtext/49leg/2r/bills/sb1024o.asp|publisher=[[Arizona Legislature]]|location=Phoenix, Arizona|postscript=|accessdate=July 26, 2010}}</ref>
In reaction to the proposed legislation, ''[[The Arizona Republic]]'' referred to it as a "nutty birther bill" that would make Arizona seem to be a place where "any crackpot whim can be enshrined in law".<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.azcentral.com/arizonarepublic/opinions/articles/2010/04/21/20100421wed2-21.html|title=Lawmakers, bury the 'birther bill'|work=Editorial|publisher=Arizona Republic|date=April 21, 2010}}</ref> Arizona Republican State Representative Cecil Ash, who supported the bill, appeared on CNN's ''[[Anderson Cooper 360°]]'' to discuss the bill. Ash stated that he believed President Obama was an American citizen, but there has been "a lot of controversy over the issue". Cooper then likened the people who believe there is a birth certificate controversy to people who believe the moon is made of cheese and asked Ash if he knew the moon was not made of cheese without investigation. Ash responded in the affirmative.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://transcripts.cnn.com/TRANSCRIPTS/1004/21/acd.01.html|title=Birthers Reemerge; Will Ash Cloud Threat Continue?|work=Anderson Cooper|publisher=CNN|date=April 21, 2010}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.huffingtonpost.com/2010/04/22/anderson-cooper-confronts_n_547766.html|title=Anderson Cooper Confronts Birther Legislator|work=Jason Linkins|publisher=Huffington Post|date=April 22, 2010}}</ref>
In January 2011, similar legislation again was introduced in the Arizona House of Representatives.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.nydailynews.com/news/national/2011/01/26/2011-01-26_birther_bill_back_in_arizona_rep_judy_burges_pitches_birth_certificate_law_again.html|title='Birther Bill' back in Arizona; Rep. Judy Burges pitches birth certificate legislation again|work=Michael Sheridan|publisher=Daily News|date=January 26, 2011}}</ref> On April 14, 2011 the Arizona legislature passed a bill requiring presidential and vice presidential candidates to show the Arizona secretary of state proof that they are natural-born citizens. Such proof could be either a long-form birth certificate or at least two other forms of accepted proof, such as an early baptismal certificate, circumcision certificate or hospital birth record.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.cbsnews.com/8301-503544_162-20054236-503544.html|title="Birther" bill passes in Arizona legislature|first=Stephanie|last=Condon|publisher=[[CBS News]]|date=April 15, 2011}}</ref> On April 18, Governor [[Jan Brewer]] vetoed the bill.<ref>{{Cite news|title=Gov. Brewer Vetoes Birther Bill, Guns on Campus|url=http://www.myfoxphoenix.com/dpp/news/politics/state_politics/brewer-vetoes-birther-bill-guns-on-campus-4-18-2011|date=April 18, 2011|work=myfoxphoenix.com|publisher=[[KSAZ-TV]]|location=Phoenix|postscript=|accessdate=April 18, 2011}}</ref>
A state legislator introduced a similar bill in 2012.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.azcentral.com/news/election/azelections/articles/2011/12/08/20111208arpaio-publicity-good-insider.html|title=Political Insider: For Arpaio, all publicity is good|date=December 10, 2011|work=[[Arizona Republic]]}}</ref> In March 2012, a senate committee voted favorably on a bill that would require candidates for the presidency and vice presidency to submit an affidavit attesting to their eligibility to serve.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.latimes.com/news/nation/nationnow/la-na-nn-sheriff-arpaio-birther-arizona-20120314,0,476900.story?track=rss&dlvrit=526351|title=Arizona Senate panel joins Sheriff Arpaio on 'birther' bandwagon|first=Ashley|last=Powers|date=March 15, 2012|work=[[Los Angeles Times]]}}</ref>
===Colorado=== Legislation introduced in April 2011 by 11 Republican state legislators would require any elected official to provide proof of citizenship before being sworn in.<ref>{{cite news|title=GOP introduces 'birther' resolution at state legislature |url=http://www.kdvr.com/news/kdvr-gop-introduces-birther-resolution-at-state-legislature-20110425,0,7792820.story|date=April 25, 2011|publisher=[[KDVR]]}}</ref> The bill was not voted out of committee.<ref>{{cite news|title="Birther" bill killed in committee|url=https://coloradoindependent.com/86495/birther-bill-killed-in-committee|date=May 3, 2011|publisher=[[The Colorado Independent]]}}</ref>
===Connecticut=== In January 2011, Connecticut state Sen. Michael McLachlan introduced legislation that would mandate presidential and vice presidential candidates to provide their birth certificates for their names to be placed on the ballot.<ref>{{Cite news|title=McLachlan sponsors birth certificate bill in Hartford|url=http://www.newstimes.com/default/article/McLachlan-sponsors-birther-bill-in-Hartford-987856.php#ixzz1Cf99Jvwg|date=January 31, 2011|first=Stacy|last=Davis|work=[[The News-Times]]|publisher=[[Hearst Corporation]]|location=[[Danbury, Connecticut]]|postscript=|accessdate=February 3, 2011}}</ref> The bill did not make it out of committee.<ref>{{Cite news|title=Danbury lawmaker's 'birther' bill dead|url=http://www.newstimes.com/default/article/Danbury-lawmaker-s-birther-bill-dead-1353042.php|date=April 26, 2011|first=Dirk|last=Perrefort|work=[[The News-Times]]|publisher=[[Hearst Corporation]]|location=[[Danbury, Connecticut]]|postscript=|accessdate=April 26, 2011}}</ref>
===Georgia=== In April 2010, Georgia state representative [[Mark Hatfield (Georgia politician)|Mark Hatfield]] introduced legislation that would require presidential and vice presidential candidates to submit an affidavit "stating the candidate's citizenship and age and shall append to the affidavit documents that prove the candidate is a natural born citizen, prove the candidate's age, and prove that the candidate meets the residency requirements for President of the United States."<ref>{{Cite news|title= A measure to force Obama to address citizenship in 2012|url=http://blogs.ajc.com/political-insider-jim-galloway/2010/04/21/a-measure-to-force-obama-to-address-citizenship-in-2012/|date=April 21, 2010|first=Jim|last=Galloway |work=[[Atlanta Journal-Constitution]]|postscript=|accessdate=March 1, 2011}}</ref>
In February 2011, Hatfield again introduced similar legislation, but it was not voted out of committee.<ref>{{Cite news|title=94 Georgia lawmakers back 'birther' bill|url=http://www.ajc.com/news/georgia-politics-elections/94-georgia-lawmakers-back-857095.html|date=March 1, 2011|first=April|last=Hunt |work=[[Atlanta Journal-Constitution]]|postscript=|accessdate=March 1, 2011}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|title=Birther bill sponsor tries, fails to get vote|url=http://www.ajc.com/news/georgia-politics-elections/birther-bill-sponsor-tries-873634.html|date=March 15, 2011|first=April|last=Hunt |work=[[Atlanta Journal-Constitution]]|postscript=|accessdate=March 16, 2011}}</ref>
===Hawaii=== In May 2010, Hawaii enacted a law allowing the state to ignore requests for information if deemed "duplicative or substantially similar" to a prior query.<ref name=ap2>{{cite news|title=Hawaii considering law to ignore 'birthers'|url=http://www.msnbc.msn.com/id/35915759/ns/politics-white_house/|postscript=|date=March 17, 2010|accessdate=February 9, 2011|work=[[msnbc.com]]|agency=[[Associated Press]]}}</ref><ref name=NIESSE>{{cite news|last=Niesse|first=Mark|title=Hawaii Mulls Law to Ignore Obama 'Birthers'|url=http://abcnews.go.com/US/wireStory?id=10121617|publisher=[[ABC News]]|agency=[[Associated Press]]|date=March 17, 2010|postscript=|accessdate=February 9, 2011}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|last=Sheridan|first=Michael|title=Aloha 'Birthers': Hawaii law lets state ignore repeated demands for Obama's birth certificate|url=http://www.nydailynews.com/news/politics/2010/05/13/2010-05-13_aloha_birthers_hawaii_law_lets_state_ignore_repeated_demands_for_obama_birth_cer.html|work=[[Daily News (New York)|Daily News]]|location=New York|date=May 13, 2010|postscript=|accessdate=February 9, 2011}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=Hawaii State Legislature 2010 Regular Session SB2937 SD1 HD1 CD1|url=http://www.capitol.hawaii.gov/session2010/lists/measure_indiv.aspx?billtype=SB&billnumber=2937}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.khon2.com/content/government/story/New-Hawaii-law-shuns-Obama-birth-document-requests/exW6-Z6YEUGOcfC7EciVHg.cspx|title=New Hawaii law shuns Obama birth document requests|publisher=[[KHON-TV]]|agency=[[Associated Press]]|date=May 12, 2010|access-date=2011-04-05|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110616212822/http://www.khon2.com/content/government/story/New-Hawaii-law-shuns-Obama-birth-document-requests/exW6-Z6YEUGOcfC7EciVHg.cspx#|archive-date=2011-06-16|dead-url=yes|df=}}</ref>
In January 2011, Hawaii state representative Rida Cabanilla introduced legislation allowing the Hawaii Department of Health to provide upon request a copy of the birth certificate of a "Person of civic prominence" (that is, a candidate or officeholder for which United States citizenship is required), and to charge the requesting party a surcharge of $100.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.staradvertiser.com/news/breaking/114749844.html|title=Hawaii lawmakers want release of Obama birth info |first=Mark|last=Niesse|work=[[Honolulu Star-Advertiser]]|agency=[[Associated Press]]|date=January 27, 2011|postscript=|accessdate=February 9, 2011}}</ref>
===Indiana=== In January 2011, Indiana state senator [[Mike Delph]] introduced legislation requiring presidential candidates to file a certified copy of a birth certificate along with additional documentation to be on the Indiana ballot.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.journalgazette.net/article/20110109/NEWS07/301099914|title=Social issues return to agenda|work=Niki Kelly|publisher=Journal Gazette|date=January 9, 2011}}</ref> The legislation was not voted out of committee.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.purdueexponent.org/city/article_43070c12-4be2-11e0-9a04-0017a4a78c22.html|title='Birther' bill fails, will be studied again|work=Ty Jepson|publisher=The Exponent|date=March 11, 2011}}</ref>
===Iowa=== In March 2011, Iowa state Senator [[Kent Sorenson]] introduced legislation that would require presidential or vice presidential candidates to submit certified copies of their birth certificates, which would be available for public inspection.<ref>{{Cite news|title='Birther' legislation introduced by Sorenson|url=http://iowaindependent.com/53330/birther-legislation-introduced-by-sorenson#|date=March 4, 2011|first=Jason|last=Hancock|work=Iowa Independent|postscript=|accessdate=March 7, 2011}}</ref>
===Kansas=== In February 2012, a committee in the [[Kansas House of Representatives]] approved a bill that would require candidates for state and federal offices to provide proof of citizenship.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://cjonline.com/news/2012-02-15/house-panel-passes-bill-derided-birther-inspired|title=House panel passes bill derided as 'birther' inspired|first=Tim|last=Carpenter|date=February 15, 2012|work=[[Topeka Capital-Journal]]}}</ref>
===Louisiana=== Legislation introduced in April 2011 by state Senator [[A.G. Crowe]] and state Representative [[Alan Seabaugh]] would require candidates for federal office to file a birth certificate.<ref>{{cite news|title=Gov. Jindal will sign 'birther' bill if it reaches his desk|url=http://www.nola.com/politics/index.ssf/2011/04/gov_jindal_will_sign_birther_b.html|date=April 18, 2011|first=Jan|last=Moller|publisher=[[Times-Picayune]]}}</ref> The legislation was not voted out of committee.<ref>{{cite news|title=Author of presidential birth-certificate bill gives up without a hearing |url=http://www.nola.com/politics/index.ssf/2011/06/author_of_presidential_birth-c.html|date=June 14, 2011|first=Jan|last=Moller|publisher=[[Times-Picayune]]}}</ref>
===Maine=== State representative Richard Cebra introduced legislation requiring candidates to submit a birth certificate and government-issued identification.<ref>{{cite news|title=Secretary of state backs bill requiring proof of citizenship to run for state office|url=http://www.sunjournal.com/state/story/983810|first=Steve|last=Mistler|date=February 10, 2011|publisher=Sun Journal}}</ref>
===Michigan=== Legislation introduced in April 2011 by state Representative Mike Callton would require presidential candidates to submit their birth certificates.<ref>{{cite news|title=Pres. hopefuls could face certificate requirements|url=http://www.statenews.com/index.php/article/2011/04/pres._hopefuls_could_face_certificate_requirements|date=April 27, 2011|first=Zane|last=McMillin|publisher=[[State News]]}}</ref>
===Missouri===
====Constitutional amendment====
Fifteen Republican members of the [[Missouri House of Representatives]] sponsored an [[constitutional amendment|amendment]] to the [[Missouri Constitution]] in March 2009 that would require "candidates who are required by the Constitution of the United States to be natural born citizens" to provide a birth certificate to the [[Missouri Secretary of State]] to confirm their eligibility. A certificate of live birth would not be accepted. Failure to comply would result in the candidate being deemed ineligible to stand. The only political offices to be affected would be the President and Vice President, which are the only two positions for which there is a specific constitutional citizenship requirement. The proposed amendment is part of a "voter's bill of rights", which would serve "as a defense against corruption, fraud, and tyranny". Political commentators interpreted the proposal as being "aimed at advancing the claims of the fringe movement that doubts President Barack Obama's eligibility to serve as president".<ref>{{cite news|first=Ben|last=Smith|title=Missouri Republicans push birth certificate questions to oppose 'tyranny'|url=http://www.politico.com/blogs/bensmith/0309/Missouri_Republicans_push_birth_certificate_questions_to_oppose_tyranny.html|work=Politico.com|date=March 4, 2009|accessdate=March 6, 2009}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.house.mo.gov/billtracking/bills091/biltxt/intro/HJR0034I.htm|title=House Joint Resolution No. 34, 95th General Assembly|publisher=Missouri House of Representatives|accessdate=March 6, 2009}}</ref> The proposed amendment, House Joint Resolution No. 34, was subsequently withdrawn.<ref>{{cite web|title=House Joint Resolution No. 34|url=http://www.house.mo.gov/billtracking/bills091/biltxt/intro/HJR0034I.htm|accessdate=July 6, 2009}}</ref>
====Legislation==== In January 2011, Republican State Representative Lyle Rowland introduced legislation that would require "proof of identity and proof of United States citizenship" for all presidential and vice-presidential candidates."<ref>{{cite news|title=Missouri Republicans Still Concerned With Obama's Citizenship|url=http://www.firedupmissouri.com/content/missouri-republicans-still-concerned-obamas-citizenship|work=Fired Up! Missouri|date=January 21, 2011|accessdate=January 21, 2011}}</ref> In May 2011, the requirement that presidential candidates present proof of natural born citizenship was added but later trimmed from an omnibus election law reform bill.<ref>{{cite news|title='Birther' provision removed from election bill|url=http://missouri-news.org/briefs/birther-provision-removed-from-election-bill/|work=Missouri News Horizon|date=May 11, 2011}}</ref> Rowland introduced similar legislation in 2012.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://stlouis.cbslocal.com/2012/02/15/missouri-lawmaker-says-show-me-your-papers/|title=Missouri Lawmaker Says Show Me Your Papers|first=John|last=Shapiro|work=[[KMOX]]|date=February 15, 2012}}</ref> On March 29, 2012, the House of Representatives passed legislation that would require presidential or vice presidential candidates to prove their U.S. citizenship before appearing on the ballot.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.stltoday.com/news/local/govt-and-politics/political-fix/missouri-house-approves-birther-bill/article_3b3a2f0a-79db-11e1-b961-001a4bcf6878.html|title=Missouri House approves "birther" bill|first=Elizabeth|last=Crisp|date=March 29, 2012|work=[[St. Louis Post-Dispatch]]}}</ref> The bill then passed a Missouri senate committee.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://stlouis.cbslocal.com/2012/05/01/born-in-the-usa-bill-takes-another-step-forward/|title="Born in the USA" Bill Takes Another Step Forward|first=Cole|last=Karr|date=May 1, 2012|work=[[KMOX]]}}</ref>
====Other==== A number of Missouri Republican politicians have continued to support claims and litigation on the citizenship issue. State Representatives [[Cynthia L. Davis]], [[Tim Jones (politician)|Timothy W. Jones]] and [[Casey Guernsey]] have committed to participating as plaintiffs in a lawsuit filed in Missouri challenging Obama's citizenship.<ref>{{cite news |last=Noble |first=Jason |title=Orly Taitz questions Obama's citizenship in Jeff City; receives support from 5 state lawmakers |url=http://primebuzz.kcstar.com/?q=node/19116 |work=Prime Buzz blog |publisher=Kansas City Star |date=July 1, 2009 |accessdate=July 6, 2009 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090705183025/http://primebuzz.kcstar.com/?q=node%2F19116 |archivedate=July 5, 2009 |df=mdy-all }}</ref> State Representative [[Edgar G. H. Emery]] told reporters in July 2009 that he "questions Obama's citizenship and ... believes his alleged lack of a legitimate birth certificate ignores the Constitution."<ref>{{cite news|last=Messenger|first=Tony|title=Missouri Republicans continue to question Obama citizenship|url=http://www.stltoday.com/news/local/govt-and-politics/political-fix/article_8b9fda22-10ec-52f5-b362-664307234caf.html|work=Political Fix blog|publisher=St. Louis Post-Dispatch|date=July 1, 2009|accessdate=July 6, 2009}}</ref>
===Montana=== In January 2011, Montana state representative Bob Wagner introduced legislation requiring all candidates for federal office file affidavits with the Montana secretary of state verifying that they are qualified; presidential candidates would be required to provide the state with a valid copy of their birth certificates.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.flatheadbeacon.com/articles/article/montana_lawmaker_introduces_birther_bill/21581/|title=Montana Lawmaker Introduces 'Birther' Bill |work=Kellyn Brown|publisher=Flathead Beacon|date=January 26, 2011}}</ref>
===Nebraska=== Proposed legislation introduced in January 2011 would have required a presidential or vice presidential candidate to provide proof of birth that includes the names of the candidate's parents, and proof that the parents were United States citizens at the time of the candidate's birth; the candidate would also have to swear of affirm, "I was born a citizen of the United States of America and was subject exclusively to the jurisdiction of the United States of America, owing allegiance to no other country at the time of my birth. On the day I was born, both my birth mother and birth father were citizens of the United States of America."<ref>{{Cite news|title=The Trouble with Birther Bills|url=http://www.slate.com/blogs/blogs/weigel/archive/2011/02/03/the-trouble-with-birther-bills.aspx|date=February 3, 2011|first=David|last=Weigel|authorlink=David Weigel|work=[[Slate (magazine)|Slate]]|postscript=|accessdate=February 3, 2011}}</ref> The proposed legislation failed to be voted out of committee.<ref>{{cite news|title=Neb. legislative committee kills bill requiring birth certificates for presidential hopefuls|url=http://www.therepublic.com/view/story/d43749240cae49e2bdb943c140471591/NE-XGR--Birth-Certificate/|date=March 11, 2011|first=Grant|last=Schulte|work=The Republic|agency=[[Associated Press]]|accessdate=March 11, 2011}}</ref>
===New Hampshire=== Legislation introduced in March 2011 would have required presidential candidates to present their birth certificates when filing their nomination papers; the proposed enactment date was changed to 2013 and thus would not have affected the 2012 presidential elections.<ref>{{Cite news|title=N.H. birther bill defanged|url=http://www.politico.com/blogs/bensmith/0311/NH_birther_bill_defanged.html|date=March 9, 2011|first=Ben|last=Smith|work=Politico|postscript=|accessdate=March 9, 2011}}</ref> The proposed legislation was not voted out of committee.<ref>{{cite news|title=New Hampshire narrowly rejects seeking birth records from candidates|url=http://dailycaller.com/2011/03/09/new-hampshire-narrowly-rejects-seeking-birth-records-from-candidates/#ixzz1GE0GNzeR|agency=[[Associated Press]]|newspaper=[[Daily Caller]]|date=March 9, 2011|accessdate=March 9, 2011}}</ref>
Similar legislation proposed in 2012 also was not voted out of committee.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.concordmonitor.com/article/311653/committee-votes-down-birther-bill|title=Committee votes down birther bill|first=Matthew|last=Spolar|work=[[Concord Monitor]]|date=February 15, 2012}}</ref>
===Oklahoma=== Oklahoma Republican [[Oklahoma House of Representatives|state Representative]] [[Mike Ritze]] proposed a bill in December 2008, requiring any candidate for public office in Oklahoma to show proof of citizenship. Ritze declared that he "does not believe Obama submitted an authentic copy of his birth certificate".<ref>{{cite news|title=Law sought to prove candidate citizenship in Oklahoma|url=http://newsok.com/law-sought-to-prove-candidate-citizenship/article/3329625|first=Michael|last=McNutt|work=The Oklahoman|place=Oklahoma City|date=December 12, 2008|accessdate=December 12, 2008}}</ref> He also unsuccessfully approached Oklahoma Republican Senators [[Tom Coburn]] and [[James Inhofe]] to persuade them to mount a challenge to Obama's confirmation by Congress.<ref name="Weigel-GOP">{{cite news|title=GOP Senators Give Hope to Anti-Obama Activists|url=http://washingtonindependent.com/24362/gop-senators-letters-give-anti-obama-activists-hope|first=David|last=Weigel|work=Washington Independent|date=January 8, 2009|accessdate=January 9, 2009|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090117002638/http://washingtonindependent.com/24362/gop-senators-letters-give-anti-obama-activists-hope#|archive-date=2009-01-17|dead-url=yes|df=}}</ref> The bill, House Bill 1329, was criticized by ''[[The Norman Transcript]]'' newspaper as "an outright attempt to embarrass President Barack Obama whose own citizenship was questioned, mostly by those pajama guerrillas [[Troll (Internet)|trolling]] on the Internet".<ref>{{cite news|title=Oklahoma's department of frivolous|url=http://www.normantranscript.com/opinion/local_story_073011056|work=The Norman Transcript|location=Norman, Oklahoma|date=February 14, 2009|accessdate=February 14, 2009}}{{Dead link|date=November 2018 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}</ref> The bill gained a 23–20 vote in favor, but failed to meet the 25-vote threshold required to pass.<ref>{{cite news|title=Bill to require citizenship proof fails|url=http://www.edmondsun.com/statenews/x519243650/Bill-to-require-citizenship-proof-fails|work=The Edmond Sun|agency=Associated Press|date=April 29, 2009}}</ref>
In February 2011, similar legislation was reintroduced in the Oklahoma state senate.<ref>{{cite news|title=Birther debate alive across U.S.|url=http://www.politico.com/news/stories/0211/49444.html|first=Andy|last=Bar|work=Politico|date=February 14, 2011|accessdate=February 14, 2011}}</ref>
===Pennsylvania=== Legislation introduced in April 2011 by state Representative [[Daryl Metcalfe]] would require candidates for president and vice president to provide proof of citizenship to qualify for a spot on the state ballot.<ref>{{cite news|title=Local reps support birth certificate bill|url=http://www.ldnews.com/news/ci_17847778|date=April 14, 2011|first=John|last=Latimer|publisher=[[Lebanon Daily News]]}}</ref>
===Tennessee=== In Tennessee, four Republican [[Tennessee House of Representatives|state Representatives]]—[[Stacey Campfield]], [[Glen Casada]], [[Frank S. Niceley]] and [[Eric H. Swafford]]—announced in February 2009 that they would be joining a legal action to force Obama to release his birth certificate and prove his citizenship. Casada, the Tennessee House Republican caucus chairman, said that he believes Obama has further proof of eligibility, and would like him to make it available: "Yes, people may say, you're just chasing some conspiracy theory ... [but] it's a simple act on his part to just do, and we're done—move on." The alternative newspaper ''[[Nashville Scene]]'' described Swafford as joining a "wacky legal action" and quoted Tennessee house Democrat Larry Miller as saying: "What is the mentality of these kind of people who continuously make these kind of goofy statements? It's embarrassing." Attorney Orly Taitz of California said she planned to file the suit, representing the Defend Our Freedoms Foundation.<ref>{{cite news|first=Theo|last=Emery|title=Four Tennessee legislators want Obama to prove citizenship|work=[[The Tennessean]]|location=Nashville|url=http://www.tennessean.com/article/20090213/NEWS02/902130368/1009/NEWS02 |date=February 13, 2009|accessdate=February 13, 2009}}{{Dead link|date=November 2009|url=http://www.tennessean.com/article/20090213/NEWS02/902130368/1009/NEWS02}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|first=Jeff|last=Woods|title=Democrats Ridicule Lawmaker for Demanding Obama's Birth Certificate|work=[[Nashville Scene]]|url=http://blogs.nashvillescene.com/pitw/2009/02/democrats_ridicule_lawmaker_fo.php|date=February 12, 2009|accessdate=February 13, 2009|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090215011230/http://blogs.nashvillescene.com/pitw/2009/02/democrats_ridicule_lawmaker_fo.php|archive-date=February 15, 2009|dead-url=yes|df=mdy-all}}</ref>
Legislation proposed in January 2011 would require anyone running for elected office to furnish a birth certificate before being declared an eligible candidate."<ref>{{Cite news|title=Birther bills flood state houses across USA, somehow avoiding Colorado |url=http://coloradoindependent.com/75305/birther-bills-flood-state-houses-across-usa-somehow-avoiding-colorado#|date=February 17, 2011|first=Kyle|last=Daly|work=[[The Colorado Independent]] |accessdate=February 17, 2011}}</ref> It failed to be voted out of a subcommittee.<ref>{{cite news|title=Editorial: Two misguided bills crash in Nashville|url=http://www.knoxnews.com/news/2011/apr/05/two-misguided-bills-crash-in-nashville/|date=April 5, 2011|work=Knoxville News Sentinel|accessdate=April 6, 2011}}</ref>
In January 2016, two Democratic legislators proposed barring the Secretary of State from placing on the ballot any presidential or vice-presidential candidate who was not a natural-born citizen.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.wrcbtv.com/story/31029457/tennessee-dems-want-eligibility-check-on-presidential-ballot|title=Tennessee Dems want eligibility check on presidential ballot|author=[[Associated Press]]|date=January 22, 2016|work=[[WRCB]]}}</ref>
===Texas=== On November 16, 2010, Texas state representative [[Leo Berman]] introduced legislation requiring any candidate for president or vice president running in Texas to submit to the [[Texas Secretary of State]] an "original birth certificate indicating that the person is a natural-born United States citizen." In introducing the bill, Berman said that the "bill is necessary because we have a president whom the American people don't know whether he was born in Kenya or some other place." If signed into law, the bill would take effect September 1, 2011, about 6 months ahead of the Texas presidential primaries for the [[United States presidential election, 2012|2012 presidential election]].<ref>{{cite news|url=http://lubbockonline.com/local-news/2010-11-17/birth-certificate-bill-filed-presidential-candidates|date=November 17, 2010|accessdate=2010-11-28 | title=State representatives file birth certificate bill filed for presidential candidates|author1=Enrique Rangel|author2=Terry Greenberg|publisher=Lubbock Avalanche Journal}}</ref>
By inserting the word "original" into the bill, Berman addressed concerns by conspiracy theorists that other bills that do not contain that word are "flawed". His bill would therefore specifically disallow the use of the [[#Release of birth certificate and its rejection by conspiracy theorists|reproduced certificate that Obama has used since June 2008]] as evidence. The legality of such a bill is unknown, as reproduced certificates are generally accepted by government agencies as proof of birth.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.slate.com/blogs/blogs/weigel/archive/2010/11/17/texas-republican-files-birther-bill.aspx|title=Texas Republican Files Birther Bill|publisher=Slate|first=David|last=Weigel|date=November 17, 2010|accessdate=2010-11-28}}</ref>
